text.headline: The First Atlas of the Earth
text.text: Flemish cartographer Abraham Ortelius (1527-1598) published the first 'modern' atlas of the world and speculated that the continents of South America and Africa were once joined based on the close fit between Africa and South America.

media.caption: Nicholas Hennepin, A New Discovery of a Vast Country in America, Extending Above Four Thousand Miles, Between New France and New Mexico, 1699

text.headline: First European sees Niagara Gorge
text.text: Niagara Falls were first seen by European eyes in 1678 by Roman Catholic priest and missionary Louis Hennepin who painted the falls and brought word of their discovery back to Europe. The Niagara Gorge would prove in the 18th and 19th century to be a key line of evidence in estimations of the age of the Earth, particularly after it was demonstrated by Charles Lyell in 1842 that the 10-km long gorge was formed by the gradual recession of Niagara Falls from the Niagara Escarpment. Hennepins documentation of the area was extremely important to geologists who estimated that the rate of recession was about 1 m per year, and thus that it must have taken many thousands of years for falls to recede to their present position. Figures ranged from 5000 to 54000 years, generally exceeding the age of the Earth as estimated from biblical sources.

media.credit: Library of Congress's Prints and Photographs division.
media.caption: James Hutton in the Field

text.headline: The Present is the Key to the Past
text.text: The 'father of geology,' James Hutton published his "Theory of the Earth" which revolutionized views of the nature of the geologic record. In particular, Hutton understood the enormity of geologic time. He viewed the Earth as having "no vestige of a beginning, no prospect of an end" because rocks were constantly being transformed and recycled through the rock cycle. Hutton's ideas were built upon by generations of geologists including Charles Lyell who laid out the philosophy of 'uniformitarianism' in his textbook "Principles of Geology". Uniformitarianism is based around the principle that the same natural laws and processes that operated now have always operated, and thus the present is the key to the past.

media.caption: A seismometer designed by Robert Mallet where the vibration of a tube of mercury causes pencils to trace on a revolving drum.

text.headline: A Major Shake-up
text.text: The 'father of seismology,' Robert Mallet, was the first to propose that earthquakes are generated by crustal movements (faulting), and that energy from earthquakes is transmitted from a centre point through the ground in waves.  His experiments simulated an earthquake by detonating explosives on a beach and recording the transmission of energy through the sand. Later, the Great Neopolitan Quake of 1857 provided an opportunity to investigate the damaging effects of seismic waves in a natural environment. He also coined the term "seismic" to describe waves of energy produced during earthquakes and "epicentre" to describe the centre point above an earthquake.

media.caption: Reconstruction of the Earth by Antonio Snider-Pellegrini in 1858.

text.headline: New World Paleontology
text.text: French geographer Antonio Snider Pelligrini noted striking similarities in the fossil assemblages of plants in Europe and America and deduced that because plants are unable to disperse across wide oceans that the continents were once connected. He actually produced a map fitting the Americas together with Europe and Africa into a single continent.

media.caption: A portrait of Lord Kelvin

text.headline: Re-calculating the Age of the Earth
text.text: Lord Kelvin is probably most famous for his expertise in the study of thermodynamics, and the eponymous Kelvin scale of temperature. However, Kelvin also infamously underestimated the age of the Earth to be 100 million years old. Kelvin modelled the Earth as a ball of molten magma and based his calculations on the rate at which such a ball would cool to have the current geothermal gradient. At the time, little was known of the structure of the interior of the earth, nor of the effects of radioactivity in warming the Earth, thus rendering Kelvin's estimate to be far too young. However, his age determination was far older than previous determinations which led to a new understanding of the rate of geologic processes and also substatiated the growing theory of evolution as proposed by Charles Darwin.

media.caption: The HMS Challenger

text.headline: The HMS Challenger Expedition
text.text: While planning the route for a transatlantic telegraph cable, scientists aboard the HMS Challenger discover a broad rise on the floor of the Atlantic Ocean, which was previously thought to be shaped like a large, featureless, bowl. This rise was later named the Mid Atlantic Ridge, which consists of a 16,000 km long chain of volcanoes that come above sea level at Iceland.The Challenger Expedition lasted 1000 days and ultimately traversed 68,000 nautical miles. The deepest point on the seafloor at 10,916 m is named the Challenger Deep in honour of the great scientific importance of this expedition.

media.caption: Sir John Murray's map of the Atlantic Ocean, Chart 1A, accompanying the Summary of Results of the Challenger Expedition, 1895.

text.headline: Mapping the Ocean Floor
text.text: One of the most significant outcomes of the Challenger Expeditions was the publication of "Bathymetrical Chart of the Oceans Showing the Deepsâ€� nearly twenty years later by Sir John Murray of Cobourg, Ontario who was a research assistant during the four-year voyage. The depth of the seafloor was determined through a technique called 'sounding' in which a a heavy rope with a weight was lowered to the bottom. Broad 'plateaus' were identified separating 'deeps' which were areas of the seafloor with depths greater than 3000 fathoms (5,486 m). The mere fact that the seafloor was not a uniform bowl-shape was surprising at the time. The origin of these enormous features was not realized for many years, but ultimately played a critical role in understanding plate tectonics.

text.headline: Nuclear Decay
text.text: The discovery of radioactive isotopes by the likes of Antoine Henri Becquerel, and Pierre and Marie Curie at the end of the 19th century had important implications for Earth Science. Experiments by physicist Ernest Rutherford in 1905 elucidated the structure of an atom as having a nucleus from which small particles could spontaneously be released at a very regular rate. This process, called "nuclear decay" generates heat which meant that simple models of the Earth's age calculated from cooling rates needed to account for this new source of heating. Furthermore, Rutherford suggested that the rate of radioactive decay could be quantified by the concept of a half life, which is the time it takes for half of an amount of radioactive material to decay, and also proposed that this property might be of use in dating rocks.

text.headline: Fossilized Magnetism
text.text: French geographer Jean Bruhnes discovered that small grains of the mineral magnetite in volcanic rocks are fossilized compasses that lock in the orientation of the magnetic field when they cool. He was also the first to note that some magnetite grains were oriented in the complete opposite direction indicating that the magnetic north pole was once at the south pole. Magnetic reversals happen every 200,000 to 1 million years.

text.headline: Crustal Motion and Mountains
text.text: In a study of the Tertiary mountain belts surrounding the Pacific Ocean and across southern Asia, Frank B. Taylor, proposes that mountain growth is caused by the lateral migration of entire continents. Taylor's hypothesis was largely rejected by the scientific community because it lacked an adequate explanation of how continents were able to move through oceanic crust, and Taylor incorrectly attributed great tidal forces as the main cause of continental movement. However, Taylor's most significant finding may have been the association between submarine trenches and mountain belts around the Pacific Ocean, now recognized as subduction zones.

text.headline: Radiometric Dating
text.text: Arther Holmes published the first real geochrononology paper in 1911, entitled "The Association of Lead with Uranium in Rock-Minerals and It's Application to the Measurement of Geologic Time" in which he performed uranium-lead radiometric dating. This technique is still widely in use today. In the accompanying diagram, the general concept of radiometric dating is illustrated, using the Uranium-238 to Lead-206 decay series which can be used to date very old rocks. Nowadays, many different isotope pairings can be used to date rocks of different ages and compositions, including Uranium-235 to Lead-207 (700 million year half life),  potassium-40 to argon-40 (1.3 billion year half life), and carbon-14 to nitrogen-14 (5730 year half life).

media.caption: Portrait of Alfred Wegener

text.headline: Alfred Wegener Proposes "Continental Drift"
text.text: Alfred Wegener, a German meteorologist and geophysicist, publishes "The Origins of Continents and Oceans" wherein he proposed that all continents were once clustered into a 'supercontinent' called Pangea ("all the lands") in a 'superocean' called Panthalassa ("all the waters") but had separated by the slow 'drifting' of continental crust through oceanic crust. A great many lines of evidence were compiled to support his argument, but like Taylor, Wegener largely failed to explain the physical mechanism through which it was accomplished. Wegener envisioned blocks of continental crust plowing through oceanic crust which was rejected by the scientific community  as physically impossible. It would take many years for others to provide an explanation for Wegeners "Continental Drift" through the development of Plate Tectonic Theory.

media.caption: This animation shows a modern model of what the thermal structure of the mantle may have been over a the past 200 Million years. On the left, we see the cold downwilling sheets where mantle rocks sinks inwards towards the core. On the right we see the warm upwelling plumes delivering heat from the core-mantle boundary to the surface.

text.headline: The Mantle Moves!
text.text: British Geologist Arthur Holmes proposed that Wegener's observations of continental drift could be explained by giant convection currents in the mantle where hot, low density mantle rock rises and cold high density mantle rock sinks. While Holmes was an undergraduate, he had been heavily involved with developing radiometric dating techniques to estimate the age of the Earth. He was thus in an ideal position to update the age of the Earth from the estimates made earilier by Lord Kelvin based on the rate of heat loss from Earth's interior. The presence of convection currents in the mantle meant that assumptions about the rate of Earth's cooling were inaccurate, while radioactive decay of elements was creating new heat. Holmes' re-evaluated the age of the earth to 1.6 billion years old, still about 3 billions years short of the figure accepted today.

media.caption: This figure is from Richard Oldhams 1906 paper on seismic waves and illustrates wave refraction at the core-mantle boundary.

text.headline: Exploration of Earth's Interior
text.text: Seismology stations with high-precision seismographs became increasingly common during the early decades of the 20th century, leading to a revolution in our understanding of the interior structure of the Earth. For the first time, the epicenters of Earthquakes occurring around the world could be located with ease. Seismology stations measure the energy intensity of seismic waves that travel along the surface of the Earth (surface waves), as well as those that travel through the centre of the Earth (body waves). Different types of body waves travel at difference velocities depending on the state (e.g. solid or liquid) and density of the medium they are moving through. The first internal structure identified was the liquid outer core of the Earth, while the last major structures was the solid inner core hidden within the liquid outer core.

media.caption: The first guyot discovered by Harry Hess of Princeton University in the Western Pacific.

text.headline: World War II
text.text: The onset of WWII triggers the extensive use of sonar and echo sounders to map the seafloor. 'Sonar' is short for 'Sound Navigation and Ranging' and uses the time it takes for an acoustic signal sent from transducer to hit the seafloor and return to determing the depth of water. This new technology was a boon to geologists wanting to know more about the ocean floor, including Harold Hess, who discovered large flat-topped volcanic mountains called 'guyots' or 'seamounts' while surveying the ocean floor. These volcanic mountains form as islands that are planed-off by erosion and slowly subside over time.

media.caption: Earthquake concentrations largely follow what would later become known as plate boundaries.

text.headline: Cold War Tensions
text.text: During the 1950's and 1960's, establishing a global network of properly calibrated seismic stations became a priority due to the increasing need to detect nuclear explosions. The United States spearheaded the World-Wide Standardized Seismographic Network (WWSSN) to fulfill this goal by distributing seismology equiptment to universities and governmental agencies worldwide. Some countries, like Canada, chose to develop independent seismic monitoring networks. As more seismologicial stations were established, a distinct pattern of earthquake occurrence emerged where earthquakes were primarily distributed in linear paths following mid ocean ridges, deep sea trenches, or continental mountain belts. This pattern is now known to largely follow tectonic plate boundaries.

media.caption: A cross section of the Kuril Islands Subduction zone showing the profile of earthquakes along the upper surface of the subducting slab.

text.headline: Discovery of Benioff Zones
text.text: By developing a tool to measure the depth of earthquake foci, Hugo Benioff discovered that many of the circum-Pacific Earthquakes occur along a discrete dipping plane that reach depths of several hundred kilometres. These 'Benioff Zones' record seismicity from a downgoing slab of lithosphere and are located at what later became known as 'subduction zones'. This motion produces earthquakes up to depths of about 700 km. Subduction zones are where tectonic plates get destroyed.

media.caption: Maria Tharp producing a physiographic diagram of the Indian Ocean

text.headline: Ocean Floor Physiography
text.text: Making a detailed map of the seafloor had become a priority after World War II. Echo sounding had become commonplace and all that was needed was to synthesize, interpret, and present the data. This task was undertaken by Maurice Ewing, Marie Tharp, and Bruce Heezen.  The maps revealed in amazing detail the poorly understood features on the seafloor that were ultimately instrumental in understanding plate tectonic theory including the structure of the Mid Atlantic Ridge and the presence of fracture zones across the seafloor.

media.caption: In seafloor spreading, magma erupts at linear chains of volcanoes at mid oceanic ridges forming new oceanic crust.

text.headline: Sea Floor Spreading
text.text: Virtually simultaneously, two geologists, Robert S. Dietz and Harold Hess, propose 'sea floor spreading' as a fundamental mechanism to explain continental drift. In sea floor spreading, magma is erupted onto the seafloor at a mid ocean ridge as two plates move in opposite directions. The concentration of earthquakes along mid ocean reidge axes noted years before supported this hypothesis, but many were still skeptical because it lacked direct evidence.

text.headline: Hotspot Tracks Explained
text.text: Tuzo Wilson, Canadian geophysist, proposed that tectonic plates moved over fixed 'hotspots' in the mantle. This concept explained why volcanoes occur away from plate boundaries, which was previously seen as a contradiction to plate tectonic theory, and also how the chains of flat-topped mountains observed on the seafloor by Harold Hess were formed. These chains of guyots or seamounts record the direction and velocity of moving tectonic plates.

text.headline: Sea Floor Striping
text.text: The magnetic polarity of basalts that make up the sea floor was mapped using a magnetometer, revealing distinct stripes parallel with mid-oceanic ridges. These stripes confirmed Hess's hypothesis of sea floor spreading. As magma erupts at the mid ocean ridge, small magnetic particals crystallize in the direction of Earth's magnetic field. Reversals in the polarity of Earth's magnetic field occur periodically, resulting in alternating stripes of positive and negative polarity on the seafloor away from the mid oceanic ridge. This observation confirmed the model of seafloor spreading because it showed that the age of the seafloor increased away from mid ocean ridges, thus that must be where new oceanic crust was formed. This explanation for magnetic stripes is known today as the Vine-Matthews-Morley hypothesis. In 1963, Lawrence Morley, a Canadian geophysicist, had his hypothesis on the origin of magnetic stripes turned down for publication as being â€˜too speculativeâ€™, but was later co-credited with Fred Vine and Drummond Matthews.

text.headline: Computational Power
text.text: Improving computer power allowed for the geometric fit between South America and Africa to be evaluated statistically by English geophysist Edward Bullard.  This was important because the fit between continents was still controversial at that point, and also because the model accounted for spreading on a spherical globe.

text.headline: A New Type of Plate Boundary
text.text: Tuzo Wilson describes a third type of plate boundary in addition to convergent and divergent margins, called transform margins. These margins connect offset ridges and subduction zones and allow plates to slip past each other without the removal or addition of any new crustal material. An important example is the San Andreas Fault between the North American and the Pacific plates.

media.caption: Current International Laser Ranging Service (ILRS) network

text.headline: National Geodetic Satellite Program
text.text: The space race increasingly incentivised scientists to improve the accuracy of geodetic measurements on Earth. One of the most accurate methods initially developed was Satellite Laser Ranging (SLR) where the travel time of a laser originating from a stationary telescope and reflecting off of a geodetic satellite is measured to a very high precision. About 40 geodetic stations using SLR still operate because despite advancements in the universally familiar GPS network, the SLR network provides higher accuracy measurements.

media.caption: The unifying theory of plate tectonics

text.headline: The Wilson Cycle
text.text: In a paper in Nature entitled "Did the Atlantic close and then re-open?" Tuzo Wilson described the creation and separation of the supercontinent Pangea. In many ways, this was the culmination of the many individual pieces of the plate tectonic puzzle. As Wilson described it, tectonic plates were rigid and could only bend at their margins. Oceanic plates form when continental crust is pulled apart. Oceanic crust is generated at mid ocean ridges via sea floor spreading, and destroyed at subduction zones. If all of the oceanic crust between two continents is destroyed, those continents collide to form mountain ranges. This is the basis for the Wilson Cycle which describes the growth and decay of supercontinents.

media.caption: LAGEOS

text.headline: Launch of LAGEOS
text.text: LAGEOS, short for Laser Geodynamic Satellite, is a series of 2 satellites that were launched to provide accurate geodetic measurements. It is little more than a brass ball with 426 reflecting prisms that can bounce back lasers emitted from land-based stations, in a technique called satellite laser ranging. The satellites have very stable orbits at 6000 km above Earth's surface, and are not predicted to re-enter Earth's atmosphere for another 8.4 million years. The purpose of LAGEOS was to enable very accurate measurement of Earth's crust in order to detect the shape of the geoid and the speed and direction of crustal movements. LAGEOS improved accuracy of geodetic measurements from about 1 meter to about 1 centimeter.  A plaque designed by Carl Sagan and illustrating the break-up of Pangea and projected position of the continents upon LAGEOS's return to Earth is embedded within.

media.caption: GPS Satellite array.

text.headline: The Global Positioning System
text.text: The United States Department of Defense launches a satellite-based navigation system, now known as the Global Positioning System (GPS), where a users location is determined via the detection of a timecode transmitted from space. Initially, the GPS was restricted for military use only, and employed only 10 satellites, but was opened up for civilian use in 1993 with 31 satellites now in service. Most commercial GPS recievers achieve an accuracy of several meters, but high-ened recievers taking long-term measurements can have millimeter-scale accuracy.

media.caption: Plate vectors of the direction and magnitude of plate motion recorded by an array of stationary array of stationary GPS stations.

text.headline: Direct Observations
text.text: Scientists at NASA use satellite laser ranging (SLR) to directly observe tectonic plate motions and find that they broadly agree with predicted estimates. Since then, the science of geodesy, using a multitude of tecniques is able to very accurately locate points on the Earth's surface and track them as they move, even at very slow rates. SLR has largely been superceded by GPS as a method for directly measuring plate motion.
